questions.text: Which of the following medications does not interfere with thyroxine absorption from the GIT?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Levothyroxine absorption occurs primarily in the jejunum and ileum.
  • Several medications interfere with its gastrointestinal absorption, including:
    • Iron (Option A)
    • Calcium salts (Option C)
    • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) like omeprazole (Option D)
    • H2 receptor blockers
    • Cholestyramine, sucralfate, phosphate binders
  • These drugs should be taken at least 4-6 hours apart from levothyroxine.
  • Folic acid does not interfere with thyroxine absorption and can be safely co-administered.

choices.text: Along with the first bite of food in the morning

questions.text: The ideal time for taking the thyroxine tablet is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Levothyroxine absorption occurs primarily in the proximal small intestine.
  • Bioavailability: ~70-80% when taken in the fasting state.
  • Food, dietary fibre, coffee, and many drugs interfere with its intestinal absorption. (Options B and C ruled out)
  • Therefore, the ideal time is in the morning, on an empty stomach, 1 hour before breakfast.
  • Alternatively, it can be taken at bedtime (at least 3-4 hours after the evening meal), but consistency in timing is key. (Option D ruled out)

Reference: Liwanpo L, Hershman JM. Conditions and drugs interfering with thyroxine absorption. Best Pract Res Clin Endocrinol Metab. 2009 Dec;23(6):781-92.

choices.text: Transcription factor defects causing secondary hypothyroidism

questions.text: The most common cause for congenital hypothyroidism is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Congenital hypothyroidism is one of the most common preventable causes of intellectual disability worldwide.
  • Thyroid dysgenesis (aplasia, hypoplasia, or ectopic thyroid) accounts for ~85% of cases.
  • Dyshormonogenesis (enzyme defects in thyroid hormone synthesis) accounts for ~10-15% of cases and usually presents with goitre. (Option A ruled out)
  • Clinical correlation:
    • Dysgenesis: no goitre
    • Dyshormonogenesis: goitre present
  • Incidence:
    • ~1 in 4000 in Western newborns
    • ~1 in 1000 in Indian newborns

Explanation of other options:

Transcription factor defects (Option B): Rare genetic causes leading to secondary (central) hypothyroidism due to pituitary or hypothalamic dysfunction.

Thyroid hormone transporter defects (Option D): Extremely rare. Cause impaired cellular entry of thyroid hormones, not a common cause of congenital hypothyroidism.

choices.text: Pendrin is the sodium-iodide symporter present in thyroid follicular cells
It is associated with sensorineural hearing loss
It is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Pendred syndrome is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pendred syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the SLC26A4 gene on chromosome 7. (Option D)
  • It encodes Pendrin, a chloride-iodide transporter located on the apical membrane of thyroid follicular cells.
  • Pendrin mediates iodide transport into the colloid, necessary for thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • Pendred syndrome commonly presents with goitrous congenital hypothyroidism due to defective iodide organification. (Option A)
  • Clinical features:
    • Congenital hypothyroidism (goitrous, due to dyshormonogenesis)
    • Sensorineural hearing loss (with enlarged vestibular aqueduct) (Option C)
  • The sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) is a different protein, located on the basolateral membrane, and mediates iodide uptake from blood into thyroid cells.

choices.text: Systemic steroids are of no value in managing the eye disease
Orbital irradiation is commonly used to treat thyroid eye disease
Corrective eye muscle surgery should now be considered
Her thyroid eye disease may be worsened by radioiodine treatment

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with relapsed Graves' disease. TSH is less than 0.05 mU/l, with a Free T4 of 32.5 pmol/l(9-20). She has severe bilateral thyroid eye disease with marked orbital oedema and proptosis. You are considering radiotherapy as she has failed drug treatment. Which of the following statements best fits the management of her thyroid eye disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Radioiodine therapy can worsen or precipitate Graves' orbitopathy, especially in smokers and those with active, severe eye disease.
  • In such patients, radioiodine should be avoided, or if essential, should be combined with glucocorticoid prophylaxis.
  • IV glucocorticoids are the first-line therapy for severe, active ophthalmopathy. (Option A ruled out)
  • Orbital irradiation and other second-line therapies are considered only when steroids fail. (Option B ruled out)
  • Corrective orbital or strabismus surgery is performed only after the eye disease has become inactive and stable for ≥6 months. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of tiredness, lethargy and an increasingly hoarse voice. He also tells you that he has been losing his hair over the past few months and has noticed fullness in his neck; he has gained 7kg in the past 3 months. On examination, he has a puffy face and periorbital oedema, and there is a firm, rubbery goitre. His pulse is 48/min and regular, his BP 142/73 mmHg.
Investigations;
TSH 70.1 U/l
Total cholesterol 320 mg/dl
Triglycerides 290 mg/dl
LDL 150 mg/dl
FNA thyroid: Diffuse lymphocytic and plasma cell infiltration
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has classical hypothyroidism (bradycardia, weight gain, cold features, dyslipidemia).
  • The firm, rubbery goitre with lymphocytic and plasma cell infiltration on FNA is diagnostic of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
  • It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas and an autoimmune disease characterised by anti-TPO and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies.
  • Strongly associated with other autoimmune diseases and family clustering.

Explanation of other options:

De Quervain's thyroiditis (Option A): A painful, post-viral thyroiditis with high ESR and transient thyrotoxicosis; not associated with antibodies or firm rubbery goitre.

Atrophic hypothyroidism (Option B): Autoimmune hypothyroidism with thyroid autoantibodies but no goitre (thyroid atrophy), unlike this case.

Graves' disease (Option D): Autoimmune hyperthyroidism with TSH receptor-stimulating antibodies, diffuse goitre, ophthalmopathy, and suppressed TSH, not hypothyroidism.

choices.text: The elderly population are most often affected
Has a mortality rate of around 30%
Hypothermia, hyponatremia, and hypoglycemia are features
Volume replenishment with hypotonic IV fluids followed by IV steroids is the initial treatment

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding Myxedema coma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Volume resuscitation in myxedema coma should be initiated with isotonic (normal saline) or hypertonic saline if hyponatremia is severe; hypotonic fluids are contraindicated.

Myxedema coma is the most severe form of hypothyroidism, usually occurring in elderly women with untreated or undertreated hypothyroidism. (Option A)

It is commonly precipitated by infection, drugs (sedatives, hypnotics), MI, GI bleeding, or cold exposure.

Clinical features: hypothermia, hypoventilation, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, bradycardia, hypotension, and altered mental status. (Option C)

Mortality is high (20-30%), even with appropriate therapy. (Option B)

Initial management:

  • IV hydrocortisone (to exclude concomitant adrenal insufficiency)
  • Large-dose IV/PO levothyroxine (sometimes liothyronine if severe)
  • Isotonic saline for resuscitation (hypertonic saline if severe hyponatremia).

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK545193/

questions.text: The presence of galactorrhoea is most suggestive of which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Galactorrhoea is the non-puerperal secretion of milk due to hyperprolactinaemia.
  • In primary hypothyroidism, low T4/T3, elevated TRH, which stimulates both TSH and prolactin release from the pituitary.
  • This leads to galactorrhoea, amenorrhoea, and decreased libido in some cases.
  • Thus, hypothyroidism is a recognised cause of hyperprolactinaemia and galactorrhoea.

Explanation of other options:

Turner's syndrome (Option A): Presents with primary ovarian failure, amenorrhoea, and underdeveloped breasts, but galactorrhoea is not a feature.

Polycystic ovary disease (Option B): May rarely be associated with mild prolactin elevation, but galactorrhoea is not a defining feature; main features are oligo/anovulation, hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovaries.

Sheehan's syndrome (Option D): Postpartum pituitary necrosis causes failure of lactation, not galactorrhoea.

choices.text: Screening of family members for hypercholesterolaemia

questions.text: A 62-year-old, non-smoking woman with no previous cardiac history presents for cardiac risk-factor evaluation. Her total cholesterol is 350 mg/dl. She is overweight and has sleep apnoea. On examination, you notice her skin is particularly dry, and there appears to be some evidence of hair loss. What is the next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The combination of very high cholesterol with clinical features of hypothyroidism (dry skin, hair loss, obesity, sleep apnoea) suggests secondary hyperlipidemia due to hypothyroidism.
  • Hypothyroidism is a common and reversible cause of secondary dyslipidemia:
    • Occurs in ~4% of dyslipidemic patients as overt hypothyroidism.
    • An additional ~10% have subclinical hypothyroidism (↑ TSH, normal free T4).
  • Checking TSH is crucial before initiating statins, as treating hypothyroidism with levothyroxine often normalises lipid levels.
  • If dyslipidemia persists after euthyroidism is achieved, statin therapy may then be considered.

Explanation of other options:

Screening of family members (Option A): Indicated in familial hypercholesterolemia, but not appropriate before excluding secondary causes such as hypothyroidism.

Lifestyle advice and reassurance (Option B): Helpful but insufficient, since a pathological secondary cause must be ruled out.

Start high-dose statin (Option C): Premature, as hypothyroidism should be excluded first; statins are added only if hyperlipidemia persists after thyroid correction.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presents with lethargy and weight loss. This has gradually occurred over the last 6 months. On examination, a small goitre is palpable. There is no evidence of eye signs or pretibial myxedema.
Investigations reveal:
Free T4 - 21.1 (9.8-23) pmol/l
T3 - 5.3 (3.3-5.5) pmol/l
TSH - 0.05 (0.1-5) mU/l
Thyroid autoantibody titres are all negative.
A thyroid uptake scan showed focal uptake of radioisotope with suppressed uptake in the rest of the thyroid. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has subclinical hyperthyroidism (suppressed TSH, normal T3 and T4).
  • The thyroid uptake scan shows focal uptake in a single nodule with suppression of surrounding thyroid tissue, which is diagnostic of a toxic (autonomous) nodule.
  • Pathogenesis: often due to activating mutations in the TSH recepto,r causing constitutive thyroid hormone production.
  • More common in the elderly, and may present with subclinical or overt hyperthyroidism.

Explanation of other options:

Sick euthyroid syndrome (Option A): Occurs in critically ill patients with altered thyroid function tests, not in stable outpatients.

Graves' disease (Option C): Typically shows diffuse homogeneous uptake on scintigraphy and positive thyroid autoantibodies, absent here.

Subacute thyroiditis (Option D): Presents with painful goitre and low/absent uptake on scan, not focal increased uptake.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Graves' disease is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Graves' disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism worldwide, especially in women under 40 (women are affected about 10 times more frequently than men). (Option A)
  • It is an autoimmune condition caused by thyrotropin receptor antibodies (TRAb), which stimulate the TSH receptor in the thyroid, orbit, and skin.
  • Clinical features include diffuse goitre, hyperthyroid symptoms, Graves' ophthalmopathy, dermopathy, and rarely thyroid acropachy. (Option D)
  • Smoking is a well-established risk factor for the development and severity of Graves' ophthalmopathy. (Option B)
  • Signs and symptoms:
    • Anxiety
    • Irritability
    • Heat sensitivity
    • Increased perspiration/ warm and moist skin
    • Weight loss
    • Goitre (Glandular enlargement)
    • Menstrual cycle changes
    • Erectile dysfunction/ reduced libido
    • Graves Ophthalmopathy - Bulging eyes - Exophthalmos
    • Graves' dermopathy - thick, red skin on shins/top of feet.
    • Thyroid acropachy - painless clubbing of fingers and toes

questions.text:
A 37-year-old female presents with sweatiness, tremors and palpitations. Examination reveals an exophthalmos and a goitre. Her GP advised TFT's which show a TSH of 0.01mU/l, FT4 35 pmol/l(9-20), FT3 3.1 nmol/l. She has positive TSH receptor antibodies.
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Graves' disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism in young women.
  • It is mediated by TSH receptor-stimulating antibodies (TRAb) that activate the TSH receptor, leading to thyroid hormone excess.
  • Classical extrathyroidal features:
    • Ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos, periorbital oedema, diplopia)
    • Dermopathy (pretibial myxedema)
    • Acropachy (digital clubbing)
  • Imaging:
    • Ultrasound- diffuse gland enlargement with increased vascularity ('thyroid inferno').
    • Scintigraphy- diffuse, homogeneous uptake.

Explanation of other options:

Hashimoto's thyroiditis (Option A): Autoimmune hypothyroidism with anti-TPO antibodies; can cause transient thyrotoxicosis (Hashitoxicosis) but does not present with exophthalmos or positive TRAb.

Iodine deficiency (Option C): Causes goitre and hypothyroidism, not hyperthyroidism with TRAb positivity.

Post-radioiodine treatment (Option D): Patients typically develop hypothyroidism after ablation, not active hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: The maximum share of thyroid hormones circulates in the blood bound to which plasma protein?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Thyroid hormones (T4 and T3) circulate in plasma primarily in a protein-bound form.
  • The major binding proteins are:
    • Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG): binds ~70% of circulating T4/T3 (highest affinity, lowest concentration).
    • Transthyretin (TTR, thyroxine-binding prealbumin): binds ~10-15% of T4. (Option B ruled out)
    • Albumin: binds ~15-20% of T4/T3 (low affinity, high capacity). (Option C ruled out)
  • Only 03% of T4 and 0.3% of T3 are free (unbound), and these free fractions are the biologically active forms.

questions.text: T4 to T3 conversion may be impaired by?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Peripheral conversion of T4 (thyroxine) to T3 (active triiodothyronine) is mediated by 5′-deiodinase.
  • Several factors inhibit this enzyme, including:
    • Medications: propylthiouracil (PTU), propranolol, amiodarone, and glucocorticoids
    • Non-drug causes: fasting, systemic illness, acute trauma, and iodinated contrast agents
    • Amiodarone is a potent inhibitor of 5′-deiodinase due to its high iodine content and direct enzyme inhibition, making it a classic cause of impaired T4 → T3 conversion.

Explanation of other options:

Oral contrast agents (Option A): They can impair T4 → T3 conversion, but the best single answer here is amiodarone as the most recognised drug cause.

Glucocorticoids (Option C): High doses inhibit deiodinase and reduce T3, but amiodarone is a stronger and more specific answer.

Phenytoin (Option D): Does not inhibit conversion; instead, it displaces thyroid hormones from binding proteins (like salicylates, furosemide, free fatty acids).

questions.text: TSH levels are elevated in all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • TSH elevation occurs in:
    • Primary hypothyroidism- the most common cause. (Option A)
    • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma- central hyperthyroidism with elevated TSH and thyroid hormones. (Option D)
    • Thyroid hormone resistance- impaired tissue response, so feedback suppression of TSH does not occur. (Option B)
  • In the first trimester of pregnancy, β-hCG rises significantly and can weakly stimulate the TSH receptor, leading to physiological suppression of TSH (often <0.1 mU/L).
  • Therefore, the only condition among the options where TSH is not elevated is a first-trimester pregnancy.

questions.text: The average daily production of T4 in the body is around _______ mcg/kg
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The average daily production of thyroxine (T4) is approximately 80-85 mcg/day, which equates to 6-1.8 mcg/kg body weight.
  • In patients with complete thyroid failure, the typical replacement dose of levothyroxine is also 6-1.8 mcg/kg/day.
  • Dose adjustments are guided by TSH measurement after 6-8 weeks of therapy, since steady-state levels are achieved only after several weeks due to thyroxine's long half-life (~7 days).

questions.text: In a hypothyroid patient becoming pregnant, dose of levothyroxine should be?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • During pregnancy, thyroid hormone requirements increase by 30-45%, so the levothyroxine dose must be adjusted upward. (Options B and D ruled out)
  • This increase is due to:
    1. hCG rise in the first trimester- weak TSH receptor stimulation.
    2. Estrogen-induced TBG increase- higher bound fraction, requiring more hormone.
    3. Altered immune system activity can influence autoimmune thyroid disease.
    4. Placental type III deiodinase activity- accelerates thyroid hormone metabolism.
    5. Increased urinary iodide excretion- may limit thyroid hormone synthesis in iodine-deficient areas.
  • After delivery, the levothyroxine dose is typically reduced back to pre-pregnancy levels.
  • Hypothyroidism, untreated in pregnancy, risks miscarriage, preeclampsia, and impaired fetal neurodevelopment. (Option C ruled out)
  • WHO recommends: Iodine intake of 250 μg/day in pregnancy & lactation; prenatal vitamins should contain 150 μg/tablet.

questions.text: Endemic goiter is said to exist when more than ___ % of children aged 6-12 years have enlarged thyroid glands
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Endemic goitre is characterised by enlargement of the thyroid gland in a significantly large fraction of a population group, and is generally considered to be due to insufficient iodine in the daily diet.
  • Endemic goitre exists in a population when >5% of 6-12-year-old children have enlarged thyroid glands.
  • Most mountainous districts in the world have been or still are endemic goitre regions.

Reference: Eastman CJ, Zimmermann MB. The Iodine Deficiency Disorders. [Updated 2018 Feb 6]. In: Feingold KR, Anawalt B, Boyce A, et al., editors. Endotext

questions.text: History of exposure to head and neck irradiation increases the risk of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is the most common thyroid cancer (~70-80%).
  • Radiation exposure, particularly to the head and neck during childhood or adolescence, is the strongest environmental risk factor for papillary carcinoma.
  • Other risk factors: female sex, family history, and advanced age.
  • Histology: Characterised by Orphan Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies.
  • PTC typically spreads to cervical lymph nodes, but prognosis is generally excellent.

Explanation of other options:

Follicular thyroid cancer (Option B): More common in iodine deficiency and multinodular goitre, spreads hematogenously (bone, lung).

Medullary thyroid cancer (Option C): Arises from C cells, associated with MEN-2 syndromes and RET mutations, not irradiation.

Anaplastic thyroid cancer (Option D): Aggressive tumour seen in the elderly, often arising from pre-existing differentiated thyroid cancers, but not linked to radiation exposure.

choices.text: The patient's results are as expected - no change in treatment is required

questions.text:
A patient who has had a subtotal thyroidectomy for hyperthyroidism is on thyroxine replacement. She has a normal thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), normal tri-iodothyronine (T3) and low free thyroxine (T4) levels.
What is the most likely reason for those results?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In patients on long-term thyroxine replacement, the most reliable indicator of adequacy of treatment is TSH.
  • Even if free T4 appears low, as long as TSH is normal and the patient is clinically euthyroid, no change in therapy is required.
  • Isolated low free T4 values may occur due to assay variability or altered binding proteins, but are not clinically significant when TSH is normal.
  • Monitoring strategy: TSH every 1-3 years once stable on replacement therapy.

Explanation of other options:

Hypothalamic-pituitary causes (Option A): Would cause low/normal TSH with low T4, but here TSH is normal, ruling out central hypothyroidism.

Poor compliance (Option B): Typically presents with fluctuating or elevated TSH and high dose requirements, not seen here.

Malabsorption syndrome (Option D): Would require excessive thyroxine doses (>200 mcg/day) with abnormal TSH, not present in this patient.
